article.title: On statistical approaches to generate Level 3 products from satellite remote sensing retrievals

multiple_choice_question.text: What is represented by the blue circles in Figure 1a?
choices: Prediction standard errors
Diagnostic locations
Prediction grid
Retrieval locations

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 illustrates what aspect of statistical Level 3 products?
choices: They tend to oversmooth the underlying process.
They capture the spatial structure of the process reasonably well.
Their predictions are highly dependent on the SNR.
They are prone to striping artifacts due to binning.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 3a, what do the different coloured lines represent?
choices: Different types of spatial covariance functions
Different levels of spatial resolution for the basis functions
Temporal bins used in the moving window approach
Paths of the OCO-2 satellite

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 4c demonstrate about the fitted covariance function used in FRK?
choices: It perfectly reproduces the true covariance function.
It struggles to capture the sharp gradient of the true covariance function near the origin.
It leads to stripes in the prediction surface.
It is overly sensitive to the choice of basis functions.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5 highlights the advantages of using what approach over fixed temporal bins for prediction?
choices: Fixed rank kriging (FRK)
Spatial block kriging
Moving temporal window
Coincidence criteria

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 6, what is the primary cause of striping artifacts in the prediction surface shown in panel (b)?
choices: Use of an incorrect spatial covariance function
Low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR)
Poor choice of basis functions in FRK
Inaccurate bias correction in the OCO-2 Lite Files

multiple_choice_question.text: How are the spatio-temporal basis functions in Figure 7 constructed?
choices: By averaging OCO-2 retrievals within each space-time cube.
By applying a moving window average to the temporal dimension.
By taking the tensor product of spatial and temporal basis functions.
By using a stochastic partial differential equation model.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 8f suggests that the prediction standard errors for FRK Version 8r are generally _______ compared to FRK Version 7r.
choices: Larger
Smaller
Identical
Unrelated

multiple_choice_question.text: What aspect of the prediction errors at the Wollongong station does Figure 9 highlight?
choices: The presence of a distinct seasonal cycle
The underestimation of retrieval standard errors
The need for a wider temporal window
The superiority of Version 8r over Version 7r

multiple_choice_question.text: The scatter plots in Figure 10 are used to assess what aspect of the FRK Level 3 products?
choices: Coverage
Smoothness
Bias
Computational efficiency
